    Residuals method for combTMB models

    residuals.combTMB.Rd

    Quantile residuals and response residuals for combTMB model

    Usage

    # S3 method for combTMB
residuals(object, type = c("qr", "response"), ...)

    Arguments

    object

    an “combTMB” model

    type

    Type of residual. See details

    ...

    currently not used.

    Value

    a tibble with residual values resid

    Details

    Types of residuals currently supported:

    "qr" refers to Dunn-Smyth residuals (randomized quantile residuals, Dunn and Smyth, 1996) for combTMB model. Quantile residuals are defined for a continuous variable \(Y_{i}\)

    $$qr_{i} = \Phi^{-1}\{F(y_{i};\hat{\mu_{i}}, \hat{\phi)}\},$$

    where \(F(y_{i};\mu_{i}, \phi)\) is the cumulative distribution function (CDF) of a random variable \(Y_{i}\), \(\Phi(.)\) is the CDF of the standard normal distribution, \(\hat{\mu_{i}}\) is typically a function of \(x_{i}\) (i.e., the conditional mean of \(y_{i}\)) and \(\hat{\phi)}\) is the dispersion parameter. The quantile residuals have an exact standard normal distribution for the continuous case.

    In the discrete case, let the lower and upper limits of the region in the CDF be \(a = lim_{\Delta\uparrow0}F(y_{i}+\Delta; \hat{\mu_{i}},\hat{\phi})\) and \(b = F(y;\hat{\mu_{i}}, \hat{\phi)})\) respectively. The notation \(lim_{\Delta\uparrow0}\) means means the limit as \(\Delta\) approaches 0 from below, so that \(\Delta\) is always negative. Then, define randomized quantile residuals as

    $$qr_{i} = \Phi^{-1}(u),$$

    where \(u\) is a uniform random variable on the interval \((a, b]\).

    "response" refers to response residuals:

    $$response_{i} = y_{i}-\mu,$$

    where \(\mu\) is the fitted value for \(y_{i}\).

    References

    • Dunn, P. K., and Smyth, G. K. (1996). Randomized quantile residuals. Journal of Computational and Graphical Statistics, 5(3), 236-244.

    • Dunn, P. K., and Smyth, G. K. (2018). Generalized linear models with examples in R (pp. 333-369). New York: Springer.

    • Feng, C., Li, L., and Sadeghpour, A. (2020). A comparison of residual diagnosis tools for diagnosing regression models for count data. BMC Medical Research Methodology, 20(1), 1-21.

    Author

    Deoclecio Jardim Amorim <deocleciojardimamorim@gmail.com>

    Examples

    # \donttest{
library(combTMB)
fit <- combTMB(onyresp~treatn-1+treatn%in%time, family = binomial(),
             data = toenail)

#The response residuals will only be normally distributed in the
#case of the gaussian family
resi <- residuals(fit, type = "response")
qqnorm(resi)
qqline(resi)


#Quantile residuals

qr_resi <- residuals(fit, type = "qr")
qqnorm(qr_resi)
qqline(qr_resi)

# }
